Authors: Meiryani, Sun Y., Isa S.M., Candra V.L.
Title: The effect of system user support on accounting information systems
Affiliations: Accounting Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Meiryani, Accounting Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Sun, Y., Accounting Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Isa, S.M., Accounting Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Candra, V.L., Accounting Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Accounting information systems can improve decision making by providing timely information. Accounting information systems within the company contribute such as providing accurate and timely information so that the company can carry out operational activities effectively and efficiently and improve quality and reduce the cost of products and services produced. This study aims to determine the influence of system user support in Development Information System on Accounting Information System performance. This research uses quantitative methods using primary data in the form of questionnaires. The analytical method used in this study is multiple linear regression with Rstudio software. The results showed thatn System user support in the Development of Information Systems affecting the Performance of Information Systems. © 2020 EManuscript Technologies. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Accounting Information Systems; Development; Formalization; Information System; Performance; System user support; System User Support; User Involvement
Index Keywords: analytic method; article; human; human experiment; information system; quantitative analysis; questionnaire; software

Title: Factors affecting cryptocurrency prices: Evidence from ethereum
Source title: Proceedings of 2020 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2020
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Faculty of Economics Communication, Finance Program, Accounting Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Angela, O., Bina Nusantara University, Faculty of Economics Communication, Finance Program, Accounting Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Sun, Y., Bina Nusantara University, Faculty of Economics Communication, Finance Program, Accounting Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Cryptocurrency market has a potential growth since Bitcoin emerged as one of the commodity investment in Indonesia. Besides Bitcoin, there is another altcoin which rapidly developing and dominating the cryptocurrency market, Ethereum. Therefore, this study aims to analyze the factors that affect Ethereum prices through macroeconomic aspects, such as EUR/USD exchange rate and the price of gold, as well as Bitcoin and other altcoins prices in the cryptocurrency market. The time series data consists of weekly data of all variables will be utilized during the 2016-2018 period. This study will conduct an empirical analysis by using the Autoregressive Distributed Lag (ARDL) test model. The result found that only in the short term, EUR/USD affects the Ethereum prices, while the price of gold do not show any effect on Ethereum prices. Moreover, Bitcoin and 2 alt-coins (Litecoin, and Monero) affect significantly the Ethereum prices. Nevertheless, Ripple and Stellar do not show significant effect on Ethereum prices. © 2020 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Alt-coin; Bitcoin; Cryptocurrency; Ethereum; Exchange rate; Gold prices
Index Keywords: Bitcoin; Ethereum; Gold; Information management; Investments; Auto-regressive; Empirical analysis; Exchange rates; Indonesia; Potential growth; Short term; Test Modeling; Time-series data; Costs

Authors: Sihotang J., Puspokusumo R.A.A.W., Sun Y., Munandar D.
Title: Core competencies of women entrepreneur in building superior online business performance in Indonesia
Affiliations: Partnership research by International Women University (IWU), Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sihotang, J., Partnership research by International Women University (IWU), Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Indonesia; Puspokusumo, R.A.A.W., Partnership research by International Women University (IWU), Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Indonesia; Sun, Y., Partnership research by International Women University (IWU), Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Indonesia; Munandar, D., Partnership research by International Women University (IWU), Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Indonesia
Abstract: Most of online entrepreneurs in Indonesia are women, but their capabilities as professional online entrepreneurs are still less superior. This study aimed to investigate the core competencies of online women entrepreneur and verify the effects on their business performance. The study uses two stages of research: explanatory and confirmatory research. The result of explanatory research, has identified two capabilities as a core competency in building superior online business, i.e. partnership development and digital marketing capability. Yet, by confirmatory research, the study has found that both strategies had significant effects on building a superior business. This model can be also adopted by other online entrepreneurs to build their success in online business. © 2020 by the authors.
Author Keywords: Core competencies; Digital marketing capability; Online business performance; Partnership development capability; Women entrepreneur

Title: Factors Impacting the Intention to Use M-Payment
Source title: Proceedings of 2019 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2019
Affiliations: Finance Program, Accounting Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sun, Y., Finance Program, Accounting Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Havidz, S.A.H., Finance Program, Accounting Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Recently m-payment or mobile payment is a payment instrument that is widely accepted in Indonesia, not only because of the convenience offered but also due to an enticing economic benefit. However, how long the m-payment provider will survive to subsidize its promotional costs. Therefore, this study examines factors that affect the use of m-payment without looking at economic benefits but focus on customer behavior. The model in this study involved two individual differences and four m-payment features and equipped with two TAM variables that explain the behavior in adopting the technology. Then, empirical examination is conducted, starts with data collection using a survey from m-payment users. Afterwards, data is analyzed utilizing structural equation models (SEM) method. The result indicates that perceived ease of use (PEOU) and perceived of usefulness (PU) are the most powerful factors that influence the intention to use m-payment. Interestingly, among m-payment characteristics, only compatibility and convenience affect the PEOU while mobility and reachability have no effect on either PEOU or PU. This result also can be an insight for m-payment providers to implement their application development strategies based on their customer behavior. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: individual differences; m-payment; m-payment characteristics; structural equation models
Index Keywords: Economic and social effects; Information management; Application development; Economic benefits; Empirical examination; Individual Differences; M payments; Payment instrument; Perceived ease of use; Structural equation models; Electronic money

Authors: Widuri R., Sari N., Wicaksono A., Sun Y., Sari S.A.
Title: Perception of internal auditor on the use of Generalized Audit Software
Source title: International Conference on Research and Innovation in Information Systems, ICRIIS
Affiliations: Faculty of Economic and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Widuri, R., Faculty of Economic and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Sari, N., Faculty of Economic and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Wicaksono, A., Faculty of Economic and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Sun, Y., Faculty of Economic and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Sari, S.A., School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The objective of this research is to explore the perception of internal auditor in public companies on the use of Generalized Audit Software (GAS) to improve the transparency and accountability of financial report. Qualitative approach was used by conducting face-to-face semi structured interview with internal auditors from Indonesian public companies. This research uses Agency Theory and Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) as underpinning theories, therefore this research provides academic contribution not only in auditing area but also in information technology. The results indicated that not all participants agreed that GAS is helping them in producing a transparent and accountable financial report. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Agency theory; GAS; IDX; Internal auditor; TAM
Index Keywords: Gallium; Information systems; Agency theory; Face to face; Financial reports; Internal auditor; Public company; Qualitative approach; Semi structured interviews; Technology acceptance model; Metadata

Title: Financial inclusion: Study from Indonesia
Affiliations: Accounting and Finance Department, Bina Nusantara University11530, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sun, Y., Accounting and Finance Department, Bina Nusantara University11530, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of the study is to evaluate the implementation of financial inclusion in Indonesia. Data consists of Micro Enterprises (MEs) with revenue less than 300 million per year. The research method used is a qualitative method with data collection through literature review, surveys, and interviews. Results show that the urgent needs of MEs is credit facility, but only 39% MEs has experienced credit facility from banks. Further, age and length of business are demographic characteristics that can explain financial inclusion. The most barriers in implementing financial inclusion in Indonesia are the complex requirement from banks. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Financial exclusion; Financial inclusion; Micro enterprises
References: Samboh, E., (2012) Bank Indonesia Campaigns to Debunk Financial Inclusion Myth, , http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/06/28/bank-indonesia-campaigns-debunk-financial-inclusion-myth.html, June, The Jakarta Post, Accessed on 02 Januari 2013; (2012) Ramai Ramai Bicara Financial Inclusion, , http://www.investor.co.id/home/ramai-ramai-bicara-financial-inclusion/39524, July 02, Accessed on 28 Januari 2013; Cnaan, R.A., Moodithaya, M.S., Handy, F., (2012) Journal Social Politics, 41, p. 183; Sarma, M., Index of Financial Inclusion (2008) Indian Council for Research on International; Solo, T.M., (2008) Environment and Urbanization, 20, p. 47; Fuller, D., Mellor, M., (2008) Banking for the Poor: Addressing the Needs of Financially; Alpana, V., (2007) Promoting Financial Inclusion: An Analysis of the Role of Banks, , Indian; Amaeshi, K.M., (2006) Financial Exclusion, Financial Institutions and Corporate Social Responsibility: A Developing Country Perspective, , Working paper, Social Science Research Network (SSRN), Rochester, NY; Mitton, L., (2008) Financial Inclusion in the UK: Review of Policy and Practice, , Joseph Rowntree Foundation, Bristol; Heimann, M., Mylenko, N., (2011) Journal of Social Development, 7, p. 107; Carbó, S., Gardner, E., Molyneux, P., (2005) Financial Exclusion, Macmillan, London; Economic Relations (ICRIER), p. 1505. , Working Paper No. 215, Delhi; Urban Studies 45; (2008) Report of the Committee on Financial Inclusion in India, , (C Rangarajan, Chairperson), Mumbai, India; Khaki, A.R., Sangmi, M.D., (2012) Journal of Arts, Science and Commerce, 3, p. 115; Shankar, S., (2013) ACRN Journal of Entrepreneurship Perspectives, 2, p. 60

Title: Financial inclusion in Indonesia and its challenges
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Science and Humanities
Affiliations: Accounting and Finance Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sun, Y., Accounting and Finance Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Siagian, P., Accounting and Finance Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to observe the implementation of financial inclusion in Indonesia. Using Micro Enterprises (MEs) in traditional markets around Jakarta - Indonesia as the object of the research, approximately 20% MEs were found to have no banking facilities. Furthermore, instead of using credit facility, around 78% MEs still utilise their own capital to facilitate their businesses. The paper also examines the personal characteristics that can explain financial inclusion. Results revealed that only gender and education could explain financial inclusion. Morever, the findings also revealed that MEs generally demand for banking facility. Nevertheless, there are several barriers that hamper them from financially included. In particular, Self Exclusion and Marketing Exclusion are the most barriers that MEs face in accessing financial services.
Author Keywords: Financial Exclusion; Financial Inclusion; Micro Enterprises
References: Amaeshi, K.M., (2006) Financial Exclusion, Financial Institutions and Corporate Social Responsibility: A Developing Country Perspective, , Working Paper, Social Science Research Network (SSRN), Rochester, NY; Cnaan, R.A., Moodithaya, M.S., Handy, F., Financial inclusion: Lessons from rural south India (2012) Journal Social Policy, 41 (1), pp. 183-205; Fuller, D., Mellor, M., Banking for the poor: Addressing the needs of financially excluded Communities in Newcastle Upon Tyne (2008) Urban Studies, 45, pp. 1505-1524; Hannig, A., Jansen, S., Financial inclusion and financial stability: Current policy issues (2011) ADBI Working Paper Series, (259); Khaki, A.R., Sangmi, M.D., Financial inclusion in Jammu &kashmir: A study on bankers Initiatives (2012) Journal of Arts, Science &commerce, III, 4 (2), pp. 115-123; Leyshon, A., Signoretta, P., French, S., (2006) The Changing Geography of British Bank and Building Society Branch Networks 1995-2003, , http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/geography/general/news-events/; Mitton, L., (2008) Financial Inclusion in the UK: Review of Policy and Practice, , Bristol: Joseph Rowntree Foundation; (2009) Financial Inclusion: An Overview, , NABARD.
